channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Briefing: Theresa May’s Brexit Deal Is Rejected by U.K. Parliament
item.media:description: Brexit supporters demonstrated outside Parliament in London on Friday as lawmakers debated inside.
item.description: Lawmakers refused, for a third time, to back the prime minister’s deal to withdraw Britain from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Syria Dispatch: A Syria Detention Camp Struggles to Hold the Women and Children of ISIS
item.media:description: More than 9,000 camp residents are foreigners who are kept in a special section.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: “I just want to go back to a normal life”: The Times visited a camp in Syria where women and children who fled ISIS territory are stuck in limbo.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pope Issues Law, With Penalties, for Vatican City to Address Sexual Abuse
item.media:description: Pope Francis wrote that those convicted of “abuse against minors or vulnerable people should be removed from their responsibilities, and at the same time, given adequate support.”
item.description: The highly anticipated law is intended to be a model for the Roman Catholic Church worldwide and requires for the first time that accusations be immediately reported to Vatican prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: The Man Trying to Make Sense of Brexit Is Tired and Would Like to Stop Now
item.media:description: Jon Worth
item.description: Jon Worth’s meticulous Brexit flowcharts attempt to chart every possibility. But the task is basically impossible.
item.dc:creator: ALLISON McCANN

item.title: In Ukraine, Russia Tests a New Facebook Tactic in Election Tampering
item.media:description: A pre-election rally for presidential candidate Yulia Tymoshenko in Kiev, Ukraine. The vote on Sunday presents Facebook with an opportunity to take what it has learned about election meddling and confront Russia on what the Kremlin considers its home turf.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: With Facebook focused on weeding out fake pages, Russian agents are spreading propaganda on the pages of real people willing to sell or rent them out.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Cholera Cases Hit Cyclone-Stricken Mozambique with Far More Feared
item.media:description: Medical staff waiting to treat patients on Friday at a cholera center set up in the aftermath of Cyclone Idai in Beira, Mozambique.
item.description: The medical charity Doctors Without Borders said it is seeing 200 likely cholera cases a day just in the Mozambique port of Beira.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Korean Leader to Meet With Trump, Hoping to Salvage His Role as Mediator
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea with President Trump in New York in September. They will meet in Washington on April 11, Mr. Moon’s office said.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea wants to help revive the nuclear talks with North Korea that hit a wall in Vietnam last month.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: New Zealand Memorial Service for Shooting Victims Draws Thousands
item.media:description: The names of the dead were read out on Friday in Christchurch, New Zealand, during a national memorial service for victims of the mosque attacks.
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Arden told mourners in Christchurch that “the world has been stuck in a vicious cycle of extremism breeding extremism” that “must end.”
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Saudi Women’s Rights Activists Granted Release, but Their Trial Continues
item.media:description: Loujain Al-Hathloul, one of the most prominent activists jailed, was not among the three women released on Thursday. She is shown in an image from a 2014 video.
item.description: Three women arrested last year, in a case that has drawn international attention, were granted temporary release by a criminal court. But the charges against them were not dismissed.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and VIVIAN YEE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tunisia Commission Releases Final Report on 50 Years of Dictatorship
item.media:description: Demonstrators running from tear gas in Tunis in 2011, when several thousand people gathered to protest and demand the resignation of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, then the president.
item.media:credit: Holly Pickett for The New York Times
item.description: The Truth and Dignity Commission published an archive of human rights violations and named President Béji Caïd Essebsi for his role in trials in 1963.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: At War: The American Intervention Against ISIS Is Just Another Chapter of an Endless War
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks carrying people who had fled the last ISIS-held area in eastern Syria driving through the desert on their way to camps further north.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: Despite the proclaimed victory against the Islamic State, the long war will continue.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Leading Prosecutor for E.U. Anticorruption Job Is Barred From Leaving Romania
item.media:description: Laura Codruta Kovesi, former chief prosecutor of Romania’s anticorruption directorate, at a police station in Bucharest on Friday. She has been barred from talking to the media.
item.description: Laura Codruta Kovesi, the former head of Romania’s anticorruption agency, was accused of bribery, abuse of office and false witness by a controversial investigative agency.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: The Syrian Detention Camp Holding the Women and Children of ISIS
item.description: The Al Hol camp in northern Syria holds more than 72,000 people from various countries. Many of them fled the last strip of territory held by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trilobites: How Mosquitoes Sniff Out Your Sweat
item.media:description: A female yellow fever mosquito.
item.description: Scientists have isolated the receptors that help the bloodthirsty insects find you.
item.dc:creator: VERONIQUE GREENWOOD

item.title: Egyptian Blogger Is Freed From Prison After 5 Years
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, a popular blogger, during his 2015 trial. He was sentenced to five years in prison over his participation in an unsanctioned protest.
item.description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, one of Egypt’s most famous political activists, was sentenced for violating laws intended to curtail protests.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Why Do Garfield Phones Keep Washing Up on This Beach?
item.media:description: Spare parts of plastic Garfield phones were displayed on the beach in Plouarzel, in western France, after being collected from a sea cave by environmental activists.
item.description: Bright orange plastic novelty phones, shaped like Garfield, the grumpy cartoon cat, have littered French shores for decades. Nobody knew why, until a group of volunteers followed a tip.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: in her words: Fasten Your Seatbelt and Keep Your Hands to Yourself
item.description: As more accounts of sexual violations on airplanes come to light, more women are sharing their experiences and taking action to make flights safer.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: The Saturday Profile: He Helped Create A.I. Now, He Worries About ‘Killer Robots.’
item.media:description: Yoshua Bengio, an A.I. pioneer who won the 2018 A.M. Turing Award with two others, supports a proposed ban of robots that could use A.I. to target humans without human oversight.
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.description: Still, Yoshua Bengio, an artificial intelligence pioneer and co-winner of this year’s prestigious A.M. Turing prize, says A.I. will prove to be a boon, if regulated.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Trilobites: Volcanoes! Lightning! And Radioactive Gas, Too
item.media:description: An eruption of the Calbuco volcano in April 2015.
item.description: Studying radon’s role in the electrification of plumes above volcanoes could help people anticipate the damage resulting from eruptions, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: ROBIN GEORGE ANDREWS

item.title: Taliban Kill Police Officers, Including a Chief, in Afghan City
item.description: The attack on Friday in the provincial capital of Ghazni killed a district police chief and at least eight other officers, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NESAR AZADZOI and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Agnès Varda, Influential French New Wave Filmmaker, Dies at 90
item.media:description: Agnès Varda and the French photographer and muralist known as JR in a scene from their 2017 film, “Faces Places.” “I don’t do films pre-prepared by other people,’' she said. “I don’t do star system. So I do my own little thing.”
item.description: Ms. Varda was closely associated with the movement known as the New Wave, although her reimagining of cinematic conventions actually predated it.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ANDERSON

item.title: Lyft, College Basketball, Agnès Varda: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Protesters outside Parliament in London on Thursday.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: March 22-28
item.media:description: Military personnel carry a transfer case for Specialist Joseph P. Collette during a dignified transfer at Dover Air Force Base on March 24, 2019.
item.description: At least 102 pro-government forces and 28 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brexit, Trump, Nissan: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May leaving 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA KANNAPELL

item.title: Huawei Shrugs Off U.S. Clampdown With a $100 Billion Year
item.media:description: Huawei announced sizable earnings on Friday even as the United States government cracks down on the company.
item.description: Washington wants to thwart the Chinese tech giant’s dominance in telecom networks around the world. For now, though, sales at Huawei are booming.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Letter 100: Deception for Investigative Journalism: Right or Wrong?
item.media:description: During a scene on the bleachers, Heath Ledger was running around “with such joy” the director Gil Junger said.
item.description: An undercover investigation found links between the National Rifle Association and an Australian political party. We asked experts: Was the investigation ethical?
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Wife of Ex-Interpol Chief Says Arrest in China was Politically Motivated
item.media:description: The wife of Meng Hongwei, the missing Chinese former head of Interpol, dismissed allegations by authorities in China accusing her husband of graft.
item.description: The wife of the missing former Interpol leader, Meng Hongwei, dismissed Chinese authorities’ allegations that he had spent lavishly and abused his power, She called his arrest politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)

item.title: Inside the Tensions at Carlos Ghosn’s Nissan
item.description: Once seen as a model of global cooperation, the Nissan-Renault alliance seethed with fear and rivalries, raising questions about its future.
item.dc:creator: HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Child Abduction Rumors Lead to Violence Against Roma in France
item.media:description: Roma at a camp that was attacked on Monday night outside Paris.
item.description: The outburst of attacks was the latest result of social media being used to fan prejudice, with dangerous, or even deadly, consequences.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Lyft, President Trump, M.L.B.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: French Raise a Glass to a Health Warning About Too Much Wine
item.media:description: Visitors tasting red wine last year in the Saint-Emilion region in southwestern France.
item.description: “For your health, it’s maximum two glasses a day, and not every day,” the health agency said. France’s response? Deafening silence.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Brexit, Brunei, Frogs: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May leaving 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.
item.description: Let us help your start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Matter: The Plague Killing Frogs Everywhere Is Far Worse Than Scientists Thought
item.media:description: The mossy red-eyed frog is one of hundreds of species threatened by a virulent fungus that may be responsible for 90 extinctions in the past 50 years.
item.media:credit: Jonathan E. Kolby/Honduras Amphibian Rescue & Conservation Center
item.description: As a threat to wildlife, an amphibian fungus has become “the most deadly pathogen known to science.”
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Quebec Proposes Bill Barring Public Employees From Wearing Head Scarves at Work
item.media:description: A protest in Montreal in 2013 against a proposal to outlaw public sector employees from wearing face veils.
item.description: The bill would also ban the wearing of religious symbols like Catholic crosses, Jewish skull caps and Sikh turbans while public employees are at work.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Grenfell Tower Study Finds Many Toxic Chemicals Near Fire Site
item.media:description: The ruins of Grenfell Tower in West London in July 2017, shortly after the fire that left 72 people dead. Local residents have reported numerous health problems since then.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Almost a year and a half after the fire that killed 72 people, researchers found extremely high levels of substances that could pose numerous health risks.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Turkish Trial of U.S. Consular Employee Highlights Rift in Relations
item.media:description: A Turkish policeman standing outside the courthouse in Istanbul where the trial of Metin Topuz began this week.
item.description: After 18 months in solitary confinement, a Turkish employee of the United States Consulate was denied release, despite American protests that the charges are baseless.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: How a Young Activist Set Off a #MeToo Avalanche in Mexico
item.media:description: Ana González posted messages on Twitter that inspired dozens of women to share their own stories of abuse or harassment.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: Tweets over the weekend inspired more than 100 women to come forward. But in a place where violence and impunity are common, many accusers remain anonymous.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Brexit Process Remains Deadlocked, but Theresa May Plans a Last-Ditch Vote on Friday
item.media:description: Protesters outside Parliament in London on Thursday. Britain’s departure from the European Union had been scheduled for Friday.
item.description: Some Conservative lawmakers struggled to keep the prime minister’s deal alive as others said that her offer to resign was not enough to win approval.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Deadly Explosion Outside Crowded Restaurant in Mogadishu
item.media:description: Medics carrying the body of a victim of a car bomb in Somalia, Mogadishu, on Thursday.
item.description: The explosion on a busy road in the Somalia capital killed at least 15 people and destroyed two restaurants and cars parked in the area.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Theresa May Put Her Head on the Block for Her Brexit Deal. It Might Not Be Enough.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain leaving Parliament on Wednesday. She offered to give her critics what they wanted — her resignation — but only if they made a titanic concession: approving her Brexit agreement.
item.description: The British prime minister made one final gamble, offering to resign in exchange for the votes to get her withdrawal agreement over the line.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Who Could Replace Theresa May as Britain’s Prime Minister?
item.media:description: Anti-Brexit protesters outside the Houses of Parliament in London on Monday.
item.description: Her offer to step down if her Brexit deal were accepted has opened the door to roster of contenders. Here are a few.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Theresa May, Betsy DeVos, Batman: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain in Parliament on Wednesday. “I know there is a desire for a new approach” toward Brexit, she told lawmakers.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG and CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Tanker, Hijacked by Migrants, Is Escorted to Malta
item.media:description: A Turkish tanker that was hijacked by migrants it had rescued was docked on Thursday in Valletta, Malta, after special forces boarded the craft and escorted it to the harbor.
item.description: Armed forces responded after a group of migrants took control of the Turkish vessel that had rescued them in the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: At Least 25 Die in Office Tower Fire in Dhaka, Bangladesh
item.media:description: Watching the fire burning through the 24-story building.
item.description: A fire official said that at least 70 people had been injured, and witnesses said they saw several people falling from the building in an effort to escape the flames.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: Huawei Security ‘Defects’ Are Found by British Authorities
item.media:description: The British report bolsters United States conclusions that Huawei, the world’s largest maker of telecommunications equipment, creates grave risks to national security.
item.description: Britain bolstered White House claims that the Chinese company poses a cybersecurity risk. But the report stopped short of calling for a ban on Huawei products.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Iran’s Allies Feel the Pain of American Sanctions
item.media:description: A mural for the 40th anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran was installed in Valiasr Square in Tehran last month.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: Iran’s financial crisis, worsened by American sanctions, has taken a toll on its allied Syrian militias and Hezbollah, who are showing signs of financial strain.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Feature: How the Battle Over Israel and Anti-Semitism Is Fracturing American Politics
item.media:description: Ilhan Omar and Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, in March, after remarks by Omar helped reveal a split among the Democrats over Israel.
item.media:credit: Source photograph: Alex Edelman/Bloomberg, via Getty Images
item.description: The growing prominence of the B.D.S. movement — and the backlash to it — is widening fault lines from college campuses to Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: NATHAN THRALL
item.category: Hillel, The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life

item.title: Imran Khan Calls for Vast Anti-Poverty Plan, but Money Is Tight
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan, center, during a recent military parade in Islamabad. On Wednesday, he announced a anti-poverty campaign.
item.description: The Pakistani leader envisions the foundation of a welfare state. But he has not yet come close to turning the country’s debt crisis around to pay for it.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
